question.title: Eclipse error: "Could not find or load main class example.MainClass"
question.body:
Here’s my setup:

Eclipse IDE for Java Developers (latest version)

JDK / JRE version: JavaSE-21 (from Eclipse’s internal JRE)

Project location: D:\Dự án\CF TDLT\Javanew\src\example\MainClass.java

Clean and rebuild the project

Checked the class name and package (they match)

Made sure the file is inside src/example/

Even added package example; at the top

Moved project to another drive

But the error persists. Could this be caused by the folder name containing Vietnamese characters (e.g. “Dự án”)? Or do I need to install a separate JDK instead of using the one bundled with Eclipse?

Any help or suggestions would be appreciated!

Clean and rebuild the project

Checked the class name and package (they match)

Made sure the file is inside src/example/

Even added package example; at the top

Moved project to another drive

But the error persists. Could this be caused by the folder name containing Vietnamese characters (e.g. “Dự án”)? Or do I need to install a separate JDK instead of using the one bundled with Eclipse?

Any help or suggestions would be appreciated!

question_comments.body: You wrote (in your question): IDE: Eclipse IDE for Java Developers (latest version) There is a new version every three months and this question will be around for a lot longer than your current version, so edit the question and post the actual version. Current Eclipse IDE (at time of writing this comment) is 2025-09 (4.37.0)
You might try the DOS 8.3 path, which would be D:\D_áN~1

Hello Fox Fox, welcome, there are several reasons why you may be receiving that message. One of them is that the code in your MainClass may be incorrect. Just to rule that out, could you edit your question and add the code?

In particular, one possibility to consider is that Eclipse and your filesystem disagree about the character encoding for file and directory names, such that Eclipse is not correctly accessing the path you specified.  Or in the same vein, it may be that you've configured the path using a Unicode character sequence that is different from the actual path, but is rendered the same way.  If something along those lines is the problem then you might be able to work around it by moving the whole project to a directory that has only ASCII characters in its path.

You give the name of a Java source file as your project location. That cannot be correct (though I don't know whether you've reported it incorrectly or whether you've configured the Eclipse project incorrectly). There is a good chance that the issue is in this general area, with the result that D:\Dự án\CF TDLT\Javanew\src not in the source path the compiler is using.
Can we see the source for your class?
Copy the command line from Eclipse "Run Configuration" window and run it from a terminal window. It may give you more details regarding the failure.
Not enough info here; perhaps try a workspace in a folder without non-ascii chars to eliminate that case.
